Issues.Title: Fix ANE in the "ListViewSubItemAccessibleObjectin" constructor (#4744) (port to 5.0)
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4742


## Proposed changes
- Added missing logic for adding and removing owner. The problem is reproduced because when getting an accessibility object for a `ListViewSubItem`, the `ListViewSubItem` may not have an owner. This is because we have several ways to create and add an unowned `ListViewSubItem` to an `ListViewItem`.
- Added/updated unit tests

## Customer Impact

An app crash upon clicking on a listview subitem.

* **Before fix:**
  ![Issue-4742-BeforeFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113000113-34086300-9178-11eb-8378-4990c11449c8.gif)

* **After fix:**
  ![Issue-4742-AfterFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113000176-3f5b8e80-9178-11eb-88d6-23780f2697b3.gif)

## Regression? 
- Yes

## Risk
- Minimal
## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- Unit tests

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- Microsoft Windows: Version 10.0.19041.388
- .NET Core SDK: 5.0.100

Issues.Title: Porting: Fixing missing 'TypeForwardedFrom' attribute
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4561 (a cherrypick of  #4715)


## Proposed changes

Padding is serialized in to Resx file and any serializable type that was 'TypeForwardedTo' should have 'TypeForwarededFrom' attribute to help is de-serialize it.
And also, we recently added dependency on this attribute, in core designer, while writing types in to Resx file.

## Customer Impact

Any resource file that has Padding serialized will fail to load it while de-serializing the type for the application. This attribute was missed while moving this type from System.Windows.Forms.dll

## Regression? 

- Yes from .NET core 3.1 and .NET framework.

## Risk

None

Issues.Title: ListViewItem.ListViewSubItem.ListViewSubItemAccessibleObject ctor ArgumentNullException
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
5.0.4

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
This does not happen with .NET Framework 4.8. This also does not happen with NetCoreApp3.1.

This appears to be a regression due to #3224, though I can't seem to reconcile the call stack with the code I see in this repository. This is exhibited in a library called `ObjectListView`. This control inherits from ListView, and overrides WndProc. After receiving a WM_LBUTTONDOWN, it calls to base.WndProc. In all cases, when clicking on the first item in Detail view, an ArgumentNullException for parameter 'owningItem' is raised with this stack trace:
```
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem.ListViewSubItem.ListViewSubItemAccessibleObject..ctor(ListViewSubItem owningSubItem, ListViewItem owningItem)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView.ListViewAccessibleObject.HitTest(Int32 x, Int32 y)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView.WmMouseDown(Message& m, MouseButtons button, Int32 clicks)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView.WndProc(Message& m)
   at MyType.WndProc(Message& m) in 
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.ControlNativeWindow.WndProc(Message& m)
   at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.Callback(IntPtr hWnd, WM msg, IntPtr wparam, IntPtr lparam)
```
This is raised when in Details view, only when clicking on a listviewitem in the first column, no matter if it is in Virtual Mode or not. This causes the application to crash.

**Expected behavior:**
Please do not throw unhandled exception during a hit test.

**Minimal repro:**
See https://github.com/StevenBonePgh/ListViewSubItemAccessibleObjectExceptionDemo
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ListViewItem.ListViewSubItem.ListViewSubItemAccessibleObject ctor ArgumentNullException" (#4742)

Issues.Title: Native portions of winforms controls are not updating their Font correctly in HDPI scenarios.
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
Net 6.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**
Some of the native portions in Winforms controls ( ex: Tabtitle in 'TabPage' or 'ColumnHeader' in ListView  or 'ListItem' in ListBox) are not updating their Font when there is a change DPI.

Explicit WM_SETFONT message is not helping update the Font but something between Managed Font and Native Font seems not working as expected. See below example ( in Control class scope).

Snippet 1:

```cs
                IntPtr hwndHdr = User32.SendMessageW(this, (User32.WM)LVM.GETHEADER);
                if (hwndHdr != IntPtr.Zero)
                {                   
                    User32.SendMessageW(new HandleRef(this, hwndHdr), User32.WM.SETFONT, (IntPtr)FontHandle, PARAM.FromBool(false));
                 }
                 var snippet1Font = Font.FromHfont((IntPtr)FontHandle);
```

snippet 2:
```cs
                IntPtr hwndHdr = User32.SendMessageW(this, (User32.WM)LVM.GETHEADER);
                if (hwndHdr != IntPtr.Zero)
                { 
                    var local = Properties.GetObject(s_fontProperty);
                    if (local is null)
                    {
                        Properties.SetObject(s_fontProperty, Font);
                    }                  
                    User32.SendMessageW(new HandleRef(this, hwndHdr), User32.WM.SETFONT, (IntPtr)FontHandle, PARAM.FromBool(false));
                   var snippet2Font = Font.FromHfont((IntPtr)FontHandle);
                 }
```

In both cases, Font from 'Fonthandle' evaluates to same (i.e snippet1Font.equals(snippet2Font)  evaluates to '**true**')

**Expected behavior:**
Result from code snippet 2 above.

**Minimal repro:**

Any windows from app with above listed controls and DPi awareness set to 'PerMonitorV2'. Drag the winforms application from One DPI setting monitor to the other.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36968667/113607096-adcba100-95fd-11eb-9e84-ec6ed5aa6c91.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Native portions of winforms controls are not updating their Font correctly in HDPI scenarios." (#4762)

Issues.Title: Fix incorrect behavior of ListViewSubItem
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4679 


## Proposed changes
- Changed the logic for getting `ListViewSubItems` for the Inspector tree: 
  * Now they are not displayed for `List`, `SmallIcon`, `Large` views.
  * For `Tile` view, we display the `ListViewSubItems` in the Inspector  tree based on the number of `ListViewSubItems`, the number of `ListViewColumns` and the `Bounds` property, through which we know that the `ListViewSubItem` is visible.
  * For `Details` view, we display `ListViewSubItems` based on the number of `ListViewColumns`. If the cell is visible and the `ListViewSubItems`  does not exist, we create a fake `ListViewSubItemsAccessibleObject` for that cell.
- Fixed the issue with getting a rectangle for `ListViewSubItem` when the `ListView` is in `Tile` view
- Added missing conditions
- Added unit and MAUI tests

Issues.Title: Fixing MonthCalendar accessibility tree
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4224

## Proposed changes

- Added a UI test app for testing a MonthCalendar control. 
- Remove all previous accessible objects implementations to create and set up MonthCalendar accessible objects from scratch. It is necessary for comfortable testing and review.
- Implement all MonthCalendar accessible objects with correct properties and actions. Add unit tests.
- Add a documentation described expected MonthCalendar accessible objects properties and actions depending on the calendar view. It is necessary for comfortable review, testing and implementing future fixes.


## Customer Impact

- Fixed incorrect accessibility properties of MonthCalendar items.
- MonthCalendar items are accessible in multi-calendar mode.


## Regression? 

- No


## Risk

- Minimal


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

- A MonthCalendar accessible object is correct only for one-month mode. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/113393004-b4101200-939e-11eb-8f51-0bdb38f55725.png)



### After

- All visible MonthCalendar items are accessible
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/113391163-c50b5400-939b-11eb-863e-698a5255d8d6.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing
- Unit tests
- CTI


## Accessibility testing

- Using Inspect, Narrator and AccessibilityInsights

- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19042.867]

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator rectangle can't  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting  the RightToLeft property as true
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET 6.0.100-preview.4.21181.20

**More info:**
1.  The issue can't reproduce on TextBox & ComboBox controls.
2.  This is not a regression issue, also can reproduce on .NET SDK 3.1 & 5.0.
3. Narrator can announce the entire context of RichTextBox contorl correctly, fixed in GH issue [3455](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/3455).

**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:** 
 Yes 

**Problem description:**

**Expected behavior:**
Narrator rectangle can  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting the RightToLeft property as true.

**Actual behavior:**
Narrator rectangle can't  focus on the entire context of RichTextBox contorl when setting property the RightToLeft as true
![CoreNewIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/113266521-f3d7ea80-9307-11eb-8a66-b8ef02effa40.gif)


**Minimal repro:**
1. Extract the application. [WinFormsApp4.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6242165/WinFormsApp4.zip).
2. Build and run it.
3. Open the Narrator tool, and press the Tab keyboard to focus the contorl one by one.
4. Observe the narrator rectangle for RichTextBox contorl which setting the RightToLeft property as true.

Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net 6.0 SDK build: 6.0.100-Preview.4.21180.17
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No, framework is not supported TabPage's keyborad tooltip
* More Info
1. This is a regression issue, found after the fix of PR: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4421
2. This issue cannot repro if don't do following step4

**Repro steps:**
1.	Create a Winforms .Net Core app
2.	Add a TabControl, a Tooltip, a Button to form designer 
3.	Focus on TabControl, go to Properties window, set TabControl's ShowToolTips as True, then set TabControl's Tooltip on toolTip1 property as "TabControl", set Tabpages' TooltipText with "TabPage1" and "TabPage2"
4.	Set anther control: button's Tooltip on toolTip1 property as "button1" --- **it is necessary step**
5.	Build and run app

Or open attached application: 
[WinFormsApp12.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6235818/WinFormsApp12.zip)

**Actual behavior:**
Keyboard to focus on Button, then Tab to Tabpage1, then mouse-over Tagpage2 to show mouse tooltip, Tabpage2 display is not correct: Tabpage2 tooltip shows TabControl's
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/113130115-4359e000-924e-11eb-9a9d-b73abc510377.png)
![TabPageTooltipIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/113129964-19082280-924e-11eb-8ef7-997a7a66c67d.gif)

**Expected behavior:**
Tabpage2 shows "TabPage2" tooltip

Issues.Title: Create separate accessibility objects for each ListView view
Issues.Body:
**Problem description:**
The `ListView` is a very complex control with many different behaviors. In the course of working with it, we found more and more criteria that affect his behavior. For example, when displaying `ListViewGroup`, we take into account the following criteria:
- visual styles
- virtual mode
- `ShowGroups` property
- view (we do not show groups for "List" view)

In addition, we found very different behavior of `ListViewSubItems` for different view.
- We do not display `ListViewSubItems` for "List", "SmallIcon", "LargeIcon" views.
- When displaying a `ListView` in "Details" view, the main criterion for us is the number of columns, and not the number of existing `ListViewSubItems` because the user always sees the table on the screen, regardless of whether the `ListViewSubItem` exists or not.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113119667-60c08700-9219-11eb-8738-c3ff6b52db2f.png)

- For the "Tile" view several criteria are important to us at once, these are the number of `ListViewSubItems`, the number of columns and the size of the item. If the number of columns is less than the number of `ListViewSubItems`, then we will ignore the extra `ListViewSubItems`. If the number of `ListViewSubItems` is less than the number of columns, we also will not display them either or placeholders for them. If the element size is too small, then we will not display `ListViewSubItems` for which there is not enough space to display.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/113120287-1ab7f300-921a-11eb-8a24-cb88da3cb341.png)

As a result, we have a lot of differences for each views. 

**Possible fix:**
Therefore we suggest to create separate accessible objects for each view.

This has several advantages:
- The "List" view has no `ListViewSubItems` and `ListViewGroups`. Therefore, for this mode, we can remove a lot of unnecessary validations and conditions, which optimizes its work. The same applies to "SmallIcon" and "LargeIcon" views, which also do not support `ListViewSubItems`;
- The behavior logic of `ListViewSubItems` for "Tile" and "Details" views is very different, so it is more convenient to have separate accessibility objects that implement their operation, and not a bunch of conditions in one class;
- It will increase the stability of the code. Since I am fixing a bug for one view, we will not worry that the fix may break another view;
- The code will be much clearer and therefore easier to maintain, because the developer sees specific behavior, and not a combination of many conditions;
- It is much easier for us to cover individual classes with tests and, if the behavior is updated, change only the corresponding tests than to update a bunch of tests every time
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Create separate accessibility objects for each ListView view" (#4748)

Resolves #4712.

- Adding TryAgain and Continue to DiagloResult.
- Adding CancelTryContinue to MessageBoxButtons.
- Adding Button4 to MessageBoxDefaultButton.
- Simplifying some code to ``ShowCore`` in ``MessageBox`` class to remove the need for the ``Win32ToDialogResult`` method.

No
